response: Make sure wifi is turned on. Go to Settings > Network & Internet > wifi, then ensure it's enabled. Restart your modem and router if needed.
Try restarting your router and device. If that doesn't work, update the network adapter driver through Device Manager.
Run the Network Troubleshooter by going to Start > Settings > Network & Internet > Status, and select Network Troubleshooter.

patterns: How to check wifi security settings

Determine wifi security standard
View network security settings
response: Use the `WifiManager` API to get details about the current network's security type (e.g., WPA, WPA2).
Check your router settings to see which security protocol is being used, and ensure it is set to WPA2 for better security.
Avoid using WEP as it is outdated and insecure. Always use WPA2 or WPA3 when available.

patterns: I have laptop hp 15s-eq2xxx ryzen 3 5300u currently it has 8gb ddr4 3200mhz. I want to grab 1 more ram stick to make it dual channel. Is it necessary to get the same model?

Mixing RAM brands in dual channel
Dual channel RAM matching requirements
response: With dual channel, the advice is always to use matched sticks, just because that is the safest option. However, in reality, people use all kinds of configurations, and most of them work. If you're running out of RAM, you're better off with more RAM, regardless of speed. Check Kingston and Crucial's configurators to see what they recommend.

patterns: Should I use two RAM sticks instead of one?

Single vs dual RAM stick performance

One RAM stick or two for better performance

Multiple RAM sticks vs single stick
Performance difference between one and two RAM sticks
Why use two RAM sticks instead of one
response: Having two sticks installed effectively doubles the memory performance that the system can achieve over just running a single stick. System performance scaling with the extra memory bandwidth varies, but there is usually a performance uplift by doing so (10-30% depending on the application).

response:
Try the following steps:
1. Run stock BIOS settings and check if the issue persists.
2. Update BIOS.
3. Reinstall Windows and drivers.
4. Try different Mouse + Keyboard.
5. Run Memtest86.
6. If RAM passes the test and the issue persists, the CPU may be faulty.

response: Ensure no other devices are consuming too much bandwidth. Also, check for physical obstructions between your device and the wifi router.
Restart your router and modem. If possible, move closer to the router or switch to a wired Ethernet connection.
Check for spyware or viruses on your device, which may be slowing down your internet connection. Run a virus scan and remove any malware.

If the Ethernet connection stopped working after an update, you can roll back the update by going to Settings > Windows Update > Update History.

response: To reset network settings, go to Settings > Network & Internet > Advanced Network Settings > Network Reset. This will remove all network adapters and reinstall them.
After a network reset, you'll need to reconnect to your wifi network and reconfigure any VPNs or custom network settings.
Network reset can help solve problems after an upgrade or when you can't connect to shared drives.

response: Move closer to the wifi router or remove any obstructions between your device and the router. Ensure your router is placed in a central location for better coverage.
Try switching to the 5 GHz frequency if your router supports it for better speed and less interference.
Consider upgrading your router or using a wifi extender to boost the signal strength in different areas of your home.

patterns: How do I reset my router?

How do I reset my home router?
Router reset to fix internet problems
How to perform a router reset?
response: To reset your router, unplug it from the power source, wait 30 seconds, then plug it back in. Allow a few minutes for the connection to reestablish.
Restarting your modem and router can refresh the connection to your internet service provider (ISP) and resolve network issues.
Resetting your router restores it to its default settings, which may resolve connection problems caused by incorrect configurations.
